title: CCTV 'shows accused's taxi' near Sarah Wellgreen's home night she was 'murdered'
text:

CCTV images show a taxi belonging to the ex-partner of missing mum-of-five Sarah Wellgreen and a vehicle seen near her home on the night she was allegedly murdered and her body disposed of.

It is claimed the CCTV images taken on October 9 last year - within hours of the mum's alleged murder - show the Vauxhall Zafira belonging to Ben Lacomba.

The stills were taken from footage filmed at several houses and farm buildings a short distance from beautician Ms Wellgreen's home in New Ash Green, Kent, and during a police reconstruction using his vehicle almost five months later.

But 39-year-old Lacomba denies murder, claiming he was in bed asleep at the house they shared, waking at 7am the next morning to find her missing.

The couple had been living together at the time and Sarah was last seen alive when she arrived back at the house in Bazes Shaw from work just before 8pm on October 9.

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

Despite extensive searches and trawling of approximately 22,000 hours of CCTV from buildings and roads within a five-mile radius, her body has never been found.

Lacomba is on trial at London's Woolwich Crown Court accused of murder where today the two images, together with moving footage, were shown to the jury during expert evidence to compare the two vehicles.

The prosecution allege that having murdered Sarah, he left the house in his taxi with an All Night Cars logo to drive along isolated country lanes before returning home more than two-and-a-half hours later.

(Image: FERRARI PRESS AGENCY)

Forensic imagery analysts were asked to consider CCTV images from the night of the alleged murder itself, photos of Lacomba's taxi, and footage of the reconstruction.

This had been carried out by two Kent Police officers driving at varying speeds and in similar conditions between 1.45am and 4am on February 28 this year.

The court was told during expert evidence that Lacomba's taxi was 'similar' to that seen on camera on the night of Sarah's alleged murder and disappearance.

It shared several characteristics including size, shape and type, as well as spoked wheels and a 'lighter tone' on the front doors of the same size, position and location as the taxi firm lettering.

(Image: JIM BENNETT)

Lead imagery investigator Clive Evans told the court that the footage of the vehicle seen on CCTV heading out in the early hours of October 10 'lent support' to the contention it was the same make and model as Lacomba's Zafira.

He added that the police reconstruction also backed up that conclusion.

However, Mr Evans agreed during cross-examination that there were no 'unique' vehicle features in any of the footage which would enable him to say it was 'the same' car.

It is alleged Lacomba's taxi was first seen on camera as it headed away from Bazes Shaw at 2.13am on October 10.

It was then spotted at seven further locations along Church Road, Hartley Hill, Hartley Bottom Road and Pease Hill, before the trail went cold for two hours at farm buildings known as Littlefields on Plaxdale Green Road.

(Image: PA)

The prosecution allege the vehicle was seen again at 4.20am and by the same CCTV points as it returned to Bazes Shaw.

Detective Constable James Greenidge told the court that during the two-and-a-quarter hours they were carrying out the reconstruction in Lacomba's vehicle, they only saw one other vehicle - a milk delivery van - on the roads.

At the time Sarah disappeared she had landed a new job with better pay and was in the process of buying Lacomba's share in the house.

He is alleged to have murdered Sarah 'in a calculated manner', motivated by the potential loss of his home and having limited contact with his children.

The court heard it was more than 24 hours before he reported Sarah missing to police and only after her family expressed concerns.

The trial continues.
description: Ben Lacomba denies murdering his former partner but the prosecution alleges his Vauxhall Zafira was seen on CCTV on the night she disappeared
